title: Components Showcase
description: All available components with examples and usage
content: Components ShowcaseThis page demonstrates all the components available in the Modern Documentation Template.TypographyHeadingsHeading 1Heading 2Heading 3Heading 4Heading 5Heading 6Text StylesBold text and italic text and bold italic textHighlighted textStrikethrough textUnderlined textHTML  This is a blockquote. It can contain multiple lines and even other elements.  Like this second paragraph.Lead ParagraphThis is a lead paragraph. It's slightly larger and stands out from regular text, perfect for introductions.ListsUnordered ListsRegular list:  First item  Second item          Nested item      Another nested item        Third itemCustom indicators:  Completed task  Another completed task  Final completed task  Step one  Step two  Step three  Important point  Another important point  Critical information  First point  Second point  Third pointOrdered Lists  First step  Second step          Sub-step A      Sub-step B        Third stepTask Lists  Completed task  Another completed task  Pending task  Future taskDefinition Lists  Jekyll  A static site generator written in Ruby  Markdown  A lightweight markup language for creating formatted text  YAML  A human-readable data serialization languageCode BlocksInline CodeUse inline code for short code snippets within text.Code Blocks with Syntax HighlightingJavaScript:1234567// Function to calculate factorialfunction factorial(n) {  if (n <= 1) return 1;  return n * factorial(n - 1);}console.log(factorial(5)); // Output: 120Python:12345678910111213# Python example with classesclass Calculator:    def __init__(self):        self.result = 0        def add(self, x, y):        return x + y        def multiply(self, x, y):        return x * ycalc = Calculator()print(calc.add(5, 3))HTML:1234567891011<!DOCTYPE html><html lang="en"><head>    <meta charset="UTF-8">    <title>Example Page</title></head><body>    <h1>Hello, World!</h1>    <p>This is a paragraph.</p></body></html>Shell:12345678# Install dependenciesnpm install# Run development servernpm run dev# Build for productionnpm run buildTablesBasic Table            Feature      Description      Status                  Dark Mode      Automatic dark/light theme switching      âœ… Completed              Search      Full-text search with fuzzy matching      âœ… Completed              Responsive      Mobile-first responsive design      âœ… Completed              Multi-language      Support for multiple languages      ðŸš§ Planned      Responsive Table                    Browser        Version        Support        Notes                            Chrome        Latest 2        Full        Recommended browser                    Firefox        Latest 2        Full        Excellent support                    Safari        Latest 2        Full        Good support                    Edge        Latest 2        Full        Chromium-based            ButtonsButton StylesPrimarySecondaryOutlineGhostButton SizesSmallNormalLargeButton StatesDisabledLoadingButton Group  Left  Middle  RightTagsBasic TagsDefaultPrimarySuccessWarningErrorTag SizesSmallNormalLargeTag Group  JavaScript  Python  Ruby  Go  RustStepsVertical Steps      1              Create Account      Sign up for a new account with your email address.              2              Verify Email      Check your inbox and click the verification link.              3          Complete Profile      Add your details and preferences to complete setup.      Process Pipeline      Input    Raw data        Process    Transform        Validate    Check quality        Output    Final result  Alerts  Info: This is an informational message with helpful details.  Success: The operation completed successfully!  Warning: Please review this information carefully.  Error: Something went wrong. Please try again.ImagesRegular ImageImage with Caption    This is an image caption describing the image above.Combined ExamplesCode in Tables            Method      Description      Example                  GET      Retrieve data      fetch('/api/users')              POST      Create new data      fetch('/api/users', { method: 'POST' })              PUT      Update data      fetch('/api/users/1', { method: 'PUT' })              DELETE      Remove data      fetch('/api/users/1', { method: 'DELETE' })      Lists with Code  Install the package:    1npm install package-name        Import in your code:    1import { feature } from 'package-name';        Use the feature:    1const result = feature({ option: true });

title: Customization
description: Learn how to customize the appearance and behavior of your documentation site
content: CustomizationThis guide will help you customize various aspects of your documentation site to match your brand and preferences.Color PalettesThe template comes with 10 pre-designed color palettes that you can easily switch between.Available Palettes          Blue            Purple            Green            Orange            Red            Teal            Pink            Indigo            Amber            Slate  Changing the Default PaletteTo set a default color palette, update the _config.yml file:12# Theme settingstheme_color: "purple" # Change to your preferred paletteCreating Custom PalettesYou can add your own color palette by editing _sass/themes/_palettes.scss:12345678910111213// Custom palettebody[data-palette="custom"] {  --color-primary-50: #f0f9ff;  --color-primary-100: #e0f2fe;  --color-primary-200: #bae6fd;  --color-primary-300: #7dd3fc;  --color-primary-400: #38bdf8;  --color-primary-500: #0ea5e9;  --color-primary-600: #0284c7;  --color-primary-700: #0369a1;  --color-primary-800: #075985;  --color-primary-900: #0c4a6e;}Dark ModeDark mode is automatically supported for all color palettes. Users can toggle between light and dark modes using the moon/sun icon in the header.Customizing Dark Mode ColorsTo customize dark mode colors, edit the CSS custom properties in _sass/base/_root.scss:1234567891011&[data-theme="dark"] {  --color-bg: #0f172a;  --color-bg-secondary: #1e293b;  --color-bg-tertiary: #334155;    --color-text: #f1f5f9;  --color-text-secondary: #cbd5e1;  --color-text-tertiary: #94a3b8;    --color-border: #334155;}Custom StylesAdding Custom CSSCreate a custom stylesheet in assets/css/custom.scss:123456789---# Front matter---// Your custom styles here.my-custom-class {  color: var(--color-primary-600);  font-weight: bold;}Then include it in your layout by editing _layouts/default.html:1<link rel="stylesheet" href="/assets/css/custom.css">Using CSS VariablesThe template uses CSS custom properties extensively. You can use these in your custom styles:123456.custom-element {  background-color: var(--color-primary-100);  color: var(--color-primary-900);  padding: var(--spacing-4);  border-radius: var(--radius-lg);}FontsChanging the Primary FontThe template uses Inter as the primary font. To change it, update _sass/base/_variables.scss:1$font-family-base: 'Your Font', -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, sans-serif;Donâ€™t forget to add the font link in _layouts/default.html:1<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Your+Font:wght@300;400;500;600;700&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">Changing the Code FontFor code blocks, update the monospace font stack:1$font-family-mono: 'Your Code Font', 'Fira Code', Monaco, monospace;Layout OptionsSidebar WidthAdjust the sidebar width in _sass/base/_variables.scss:1$sidebar-width: 280px; // Default widthContainer WidthChange the maximum content width:1$container-max-width: 1280px; // Default max widthHeader HeightModify the header height:1$header-height: 64px; // Default heightDisabling FeaturesYou can disable certain features in _config.yml:1234# Theme settingsenable_dark_mode: false  # Disable dark mode toggleenable_search: false     # Disable search functionalityenable_tags: false       # Disable tagging systemAdvanced CustomizationCustom ComponentsCreate new components in the _sass/components/ directory:123456789101112// _sass/components/_custom-card.scss.custom-card {  background: var(--color-bg-secondary);  border: 1px solid var(--color-border);  border-radius: var(--radius-lg);  padding: var(--spacing-6);    &:hover {    box-shadow: var(--shadow-lg);    transform: translateY(-2px);  }}Overriding LayoutsCopy any layout from _layouts/ to your project and modify as needed. Jekyll will use your version instead of the themeâ€™s default.Custom JavaScriptAdd custom JavaScript by creating assets/js/custom.js and including it in the layout:1234// Custom functionalitydocument.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {  // Your code here});Best Practices  Use CSS Variables: Leverage the existing CSS custom properties for consistency  Test Dark Mode: Always test your customizations in both light and dark modes  Mobile First: Ensure customizations work well on mobile devices  Performance: Minimize custom CSS and JavaScript for optimal performance  Accessibility: Maintain proper color contrast ratios when customizing colors

title: Docker Development Guide
description: Complete guide for using Docker to develop your documentation locally
content: Docker Development GuideThis guide explains how to use Docker for local development of your documentation site without installing Ruby, Jekyll, or any other dependencies on your machine.Why Docker?Using Docker for local development provides several benefits:  No Installation Required - No need to install Ruby, Jekyll, or manage gem dependencies  Consistent Environment - Same environment across all team members and machines  Clean System - Doesnâ€™t pollute your system with global installations  Easy Updates - Update dependencies by rebuilding the container  Multiple Projects - Run different Jekyll versions for different projects  Platform Independent - Works the same on Windows, macOS, and LinuxQuick Start      1              Install Docker      Download and install Docker Desktop from docker.com              2              Clone Repository      Clone your documentation repository to your local machine      git clone https://github.com/yourusername/docs-template.gitcd docs-template              3          Start Development Server      Run Docker Compose to start the Jekyll server      docker-compose up      Once running, access your site at http://localhost:4000. The server includes:  Live Reload - Changes automatically refresh in your browser  File Watching - All file changes are detected  Error Messages - Build errors appear in the terminalDocker CommandsBasic Commands            Command      Description                  docker-compose up      Start the development server              docker-compose up -d      Start in background (detached mode)              docker-compose down      Stop the server              docker-compose logs -f      View server logs              docker-compose build      Rebuild the container      Development Workflow12345678# Start developmentdocker-compose up# Make your changes - files are automatically synced# The browser will auto-reload when you save files# Stop when donedocker-compose downAdvanced Commands1234567891011# Rebuild after changing Gemfiledocker-compose build --no-cache# Run a specific Jekyll commanddocker-compose run jekyll bundle exec jekyll build# Access the container shelldocker-compose run jekyll bash# Clean up everything (including volumes)docker-compose down -vContainer DetailsThe Docker setup includes:Dockerfile Configuration  Base Image: Ruby 3.0 slim for smaller size  Dependencies: Build tools, Git, Node.js  Jekyll: Latest version with all plugins  Ports: 4000 (Jekyll) and 35729 (LiveReload)Docker Compose Features  Volume Mounting: Your local files are synced to the container  Bundle Cache: Gems are cached for faster rebuilds  Development Config: Uses _config_dev.yml for local settings  Force Polling: Ensures file changes are detected on all systemsFile Structure12345docs-template/â”œâ”€â”€ Dockerfile          # Container configurationâ”œâ”€â”€ docker-compose.yml  # Service orchestrationâ”œâ”€â”€ .dockerignore      # Files to exclude from containerâ””â”€â”€ _config_dev.yml    # Development-specific Jekyll configTroubleshootingCommon Issues and SolutionsPort Already in Use1234# Error: bind: address already in use# Solution: Change the port in docker-compose.ymlports:  - "4001:4000"  # Use 4001 insteadFiles Not Updating123# Solution: Force polling is enabled by default# If still having issues, restart the containerdocker-compose restartPermission Errors12# On Linux, you might need to fix ownershipsudo chown -R $USER:$USER .Slow Performance on Windows12# Use WSL2 for better performance# Run Docker and your files inside WSL2Debugging Tips  Check Logs: Always check docker-compose logs -f for errors  Rebuild Clean: Try docker-compose down -v && docker-compose build  Container Shell: Access with docker-compose run jekyll bash  Jekyll Version: Check with docker-compose run jekyll jekyll -vPerformance OptimizationTips for Better Performance  Use .dockerignore to exclude large files  Mount only necessary directories  Use Docker Desktopâ€™s resource settings  Enable virtualization in BIOS  Keep Docker Desktop updatedResource ConfigurationIn Docker Desktop settings:  CPUs: Allocate at least 2 CPUs  Memory: Allocate at least 2GB RAM  Disk: Ensure adequate disk spaceDocker vs Traditional Setup            Feature      Docker      Traditional                  Setup Time      ~5 minutes      ~20-30 minutes              Ruby Installation      Not needed      Required              Dependency Management      Automatic      Manual              System Impact      None      Global gems              Version Conflicts      Isolated      Possible              Team Consistency      Guaranteed      Varies      Next StepsNow that you have Docker development running:  Make Changes: Edit files in your favorite editor  See Results: Changes appear instantly at http://localhost:4000  Test Production: Build with docker-compose run jekyll jekyll build  Deploy: Push to GitHub for automatic GitHub Pages deployment  Pro Tip: You can run multiple documentation projects simultaneously by using different ports in docker-compose.yml!

title: Getting Started
description: Quick start guide to get your documentation site up and running
content: Getting StartedWelcome to the Modern Documentation Template! This guide will help you get your documentation site up and running in just a few minutes.PrerequisitesBefore you begin, make sure you have:  A GitHub account  Basic knowledge of Markdown  A text editor (VS Code, Sublime Text, etc.)For local development (optional):  Ruby 2.5.0 or higher  RubyGems  GCC and MakeInstallationMethod 1: Using GitHub Pages (Recommended)      1              Fork the Repository      Click the "Fork" button on the repository page to create your own copy.              2              Enable GitHub Pages      Go to Settings â†’ Pages and configure the source branch.              3          Access Your Site      Your site will be available at https://[username].github.io/[repository-name]/      Method 2: Local Development with Docker (Recommended)No installation required! Use Docker for a clean development environment:12345678# Clone your forkgit clone https://github.com/yourusername/docs-template.gitcd docs-template# Start with Docker Composedocker-compose up# Open http://localhost:4000 in your browser  Why Docker? No need to install Ruby, Jekyll, or any dependencies. Everything runs in an isolated container, keeping your system clean.Method 3: Traditional Local DevelopmentIf you prefer to install Jekyll directly:1234567891011# Clone your forkgit clone https://github.com/yourusername/docs-template.gitcd docs-template# Install dependenciesbundle install# Run locallybundle exec jekyll serve# Open http://localhost:4000 in your browserFirst StepsOnce your site is running, here are the first things you should do:1. Configure Your SiteEdit _config.yml to customize your site:123title: My Documentationdescription: Documentation for my awesome projecttheme_color: "blue" # Choose your color palette2. Add Your First PageCreate a new file in the _docs folder:123456789101112---layout: doctitle: My First Pagedescription: This is my first documentation pagetags: [example]order: 1section: Getting Started---# My First PageYour content goes here...3. Customize NavigationUpdate the navigation in _config.yml:1234567navigation:  - title: Home    url: /  - title: Docs    url: /docs/  - title: About    url: /about/4. Choose a Color PaletteThe template includes 10 beautiful color palettes. Try them out by clicking the palette icon in the header!  Tip: You can set a default palette in _config.yml with the theme_color setting.Whatâ€™s Next?Now that you have your documentation site running, explore these resources:  Writing Documentation - Learn about Markdown features and components  Customization Guide - Make the template your own  Components Reference - See all available components  Deployment Guide - Deploy to custom domains  Success! You're ready to start creating beautiful documentation.

title: Documentation
description: Complete documentation for the Modern Documentation Template
content: DocumentationWelcome to the documentation for the Modern Documentation Template. This documentation will guide you through all aspects of using and customizing the template.Quick Links       Getting Started    Learn how to set up and configure your documentation site.    Get Started           Docker Development    Set up a clean local development environment with Docker.    Docker Guide           Components    Explore all available UI components and how to use them.    View Components           Customization    Learn how to customize themes, colors, and layouts.    Customize  Features  Modern Design: Clean, responsive layout that looks great on all devices  10 Color Palettes: Choose from 10 pre-designed color schemes  Dark Mode: Full dark mode support for all color palettes  Search: Fast, client-side search powered by Lunr.js  Tags: Organize content with a comprehensive tagging system  Code Highlighting: Beautiful syntax highlighting with copy functionality  GitHub Pages Ready: Deploy directly to GitHub PagesGetting HelpIf you encounter any issues or have questions:  Check the documentation  Search for existing issues on GitHub  Create a new issue if neededContributingWe welcome contributions! Please see our contributing guidelines for more information.

title: Modern Documentation Template
description: A beautiful, modern documentation template for GitHub Pages with stunning design and powerful features
content: Beautiful Documentation Made Simple  Create stunning documentation sites with our modern Jekyll template. Features dark mode, search, multiple color palettes, and beautiful components.              Get Started                View on GitHub      âœ¨ Key Features                    10 Color Palettes    Choose from 10 beautiful color palettes, each with full dark mode support. Easy to customize and extend.                        Powerful Search    Built-in search functionality with real-time results, fuzzy matching, and keyboard navigation.                        Dark Mode    Automatic dark mode support for all color palettes. Respects system preferences and saves user choice.                        Fully Responsive    Mobile-first design that looks great on all devices. Optimized navigation and reading experience.                        Rich Components    Code blocks with syntax highlighting, tables, custom lists, step-by-step guides, and more.                        Tagging System    Organize content with tags. Filter and search by tags to quickly find relevant documentation.  ðŸš€ Quick Start1234# 1. Fork this repository# 2. Enable GitHub Pages in your repository settings# 3. Choose your color palette in _config.yml# 4. Start adding your documentation in the _docs folderðŸŽ¨ Color Palettes          Blue            Purple            Green            Orange            Red            Teal            Pink            Indigo            Amber            Slate
